newsitem.title: USA: Federal jury considers fate of Arizona governor.
newsitem.headline: Federal jury considers fate of Arizona governor.

text.p: A federal jury began deliberations Friday to decide whether Arizona Gov. Fife Symington lied to banks to prevent the real estate empire he developed from collapsing.
Symington, 51, faces 19 counts of federal bank fraud stemming from his real estate dealings in the mid-1980s to early 1990s. He also is charged with one count each of attempted extortion and perjury.
After receiving instructions from U.S. District Court Judge Roger Strand, the jury began its deliberations following 13 weeks of testimony, including six days from Symington, a two-term governor.
The seven-man, five-woman jury will work weekdays until it reaches a unamimous verdict or there is an impasse.
The state's Republican chief executive would be forced from the office he has held since 1991 if convicted on a single count. He could also face a prison term.
Prosecutors depicted Symington as a well-educated liar, who manipulated lenders to get millions in loans.
The government also pressed hard on allegations that Symington abused his office in seeking to change his loan agreement with six labour unions.
The unions provided $10 million to build an office-retail project in downtown Phoenix.
Prosecutors also have tried to prove that Symington lied during bankruptcy proceedings about one of his financial statements. He filed for bankruptcy in September 1995.
